facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1953 and connected Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954 were heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1953 and companynected appeal  C.A. No. 12 of 1954 . Appeals from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeals arose from High Court of Patna judgment dated 11th May 1951 in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 253 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the Judgment and Decree dated the 11th day of May 1951 of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 253 of 1950

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad passed order dated 11th May 1951 in Suit No. 34 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and in appeal from Original Order No. 252 of 1950 arising out of the order dated the 11th day of May 1951 of the Court of Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad in Suit No. 34 of 1949

facts.text: Contractor entered into contract with Dominion of India on 1-11-1945 for supply of bricks to C.P.W.D.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us, whom it will be companyvenient to call the companytractor, entered into a companytract with the Dominion of India through an Additional Chief Engineer of the C.P.W.D. on 1-11-1945 for the supply of bricks to the C.P.W.D., a department of the Dominion Government.

facts.text: Disputes referred to Superintending Engineer on 21-1-1949, award given on 8-5-1949.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, there was a reference on 21-1-1949 and an award followed on 8-5-1949.

facts.text: Award filed in Court of Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad; contractor prayed for decree in terms of award.

anchor.surface_text: It was filed in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad, and the companytractor prayed that it be accepted and that a decree be passed in terms of it.

facts.text: Dominion of India filed objections under section 30 of Arbitration Act, prayed award be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The Dominion of India filed objections under section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 and prayed that the award be set aside and alternatively that it be modified or companyrected.

facts.text: Decree passed in terms of award on 18-3-1950; Union of India replaced Dominion as defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The companytractors application was registered as a suit under section 20 2  of the Act and a decree was passed in terms of the award on 18-3-1950. By that time the Constitution had companye into force and the Union of India replaced the Dominion of India as a defendant.

facts.text: Union of India appealed to High Court; appeal allowed in part.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India filed an appeal to the High Court. The appeal was allowed in part. The companytractor thereupon appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Contract for supply of 2-1/2 crores pucca bricks with delivery schedule: 30 lacs by 25-1-46, 50 lacs by 25-2-46, etc. up to 60 lacs by 25-5-46.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract was for the supply of 2-1/2 crores of pucca bricks which bad to be delivered according to the following schedule- 30 lacs by 25-1-46 50 lacs by 25-2-46 55 lacs by 25-3-46 55 lacs by 25-4-46 60 lacs by 25-5-46.

facts.text: C.P.W.D. failed to remove baked bricks ready for delivery, causing jam in kilns and accumulation of 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain.

anchor.surface_text: At a certain stage of the companytract the P.W.D. failed to remove the baked bricks which were ready for delivery and removal. This caused a jam in the kilns and prevented the companytractor from placing a fresh stock of unburnt bricks in the kilns, and in the meanwhile his stock pile of katcha bricks ready for baking kept on mounting up. ... the rains set in with the result that88 lacs of katcha bricks were destroyed by the rains.

facts.text: Contractor claimed Rs. 75,900 for 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed; arbitrator awarded Rs. 64,075.

anchor.surface_text: In the 5th head of claim the companytractor claimed Rs. 75,900 ... the arbitrator ... awarded the companytractor Rs. 64,075 under this head.

facts.text: Clause 6 of agreement: Department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: The Union Government relied on additional clause 6 of the agreement which is in these terms The department will number entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

facts.text: Supreme Court held arbitrator erred in law by awarding on item 5, as clause 6 bars claim.

anchor.surface_text: We are clear that the arbitrator went wrong in law. ... There can therefore be numberdoubt that the arbitrator was wrong in his law.

facts.text: Contractor awarded Rs. 11,744-11-0 under claim No. 4 for extra labour stacking bricks.

anchor.surface_text: He has been awarded Rs. 11,744-11-0 under claim No. 4 for the extra load in companynection with the stacking of I crore 7 lacs of bricks

facts.text: Contractor claimed Rs. 51,495 under item 8 for additional wages due to non-supply of ration and cloth.

anchor.surface_text: The next head in dispute is item No. 8 in the statement of claim Cost of additional wages paid to the companylies on account of number-supply of ration and cloth-Rs. 51,495.

facts.text: Tender submitted 25-9-1945, accepted 1-11-1945, contract signed 22-11-1945.

anchor.surface_text: The companytractor stated that when he submitted his tender on 25-9-45 he did so ... On 1-11-45 the companytractor was told that his tender had been accepted. ... The companytract was finally accepted and signed on 22-11-45.

facts.text: Arbitrator awarded Rs. 40,000 under item 8; Supreme Court held error of law apparent on face of award.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly awarded Rs. 40,000 as companypensation under this head. The error is apparent.

facts.text: Contractor claimed interest Rs. 27,665 under item 17 for 16 months from 1-1-1948.

anchor.surface_text: Item 17-Interest on the amount of money involved in this claim at the rate of Rs. 6 percent.Rs. 27,665. ... We therefore pray for interest for 16 months from 1-1-48 to 31-4-49.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 24, 1955 by BOSE J.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. March 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-This appeal and Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954, which will also be governed by this judgment, raise the same points

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954, contract signed on same day as other, award on 1-5-1949.

anchor.surface_text: It was signed on the same day as the other and by the same authority ... the award in this case was given on 1-5-1949, one week before the other award.

facts.text: High Court dismissed claims under disputed heads in Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in dismissing the claims made under the heads in dispute here.

arguments.claim: Contractor entitled to Rs. 75,900 for 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain due to C.P.W.D.'s failure to remove baked bricks on time

anchor.surface_text: In the 5th head of claim the contractor claimed Rs. 75,900 as the price of 88 lacs of katcha bricks that were destroyed by rain. These bricks were not the subject-matter of the contract but the contractor put his claim in this way. The contract was for the supply of 2-1/2 crores of pucca bricks which had to be delivered according to the following schedule- 30 lacs by 25-1-46 50 lacs by 25-2-46 55 lacs by 25-3-46 55 lacs by 25-4-46 60 lacs by 25-5-46.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: they chose to provide against such a companytingency by making clause 6 an express clause in their companytract. There can therefore be numberdoubt th

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause 6 expressly bars claims for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause; loss too remote; duty to mitigate under s.73 Contract Act

arguments.claim: Katcha bricks not part of contract; loss too remote even if fault in taking delivery

anchor.surface_text: The reply of the Union Government was two-fold. First, it contended that the katcha bricks formed no part of the contract and even if it was at fault in not taking delivery of the burnt bricks in time all that it could be held liable for would be for breach of that contract and said that the loss that was occasioned by the damage caused to the katcha bricks which formed no part of the contract was too remote.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: for the view that the Courts will interfere if it is apparent that the arbitrator has acted illegally in reaching his decision, that is to say, if he

arguments.court_reasoning: Loss remote unless contemplated; clause 6 excludes; duty to mitigate

arguments.claim: Clause 6 bars any claim for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, that compensation for this loss could not in any event be claimed because this kind of situation was envisaged by the parties when the contract was made and they expressly stipulated that the Dominion Government would not be responsible. The Union Government relied on additional clause 6 of the agreement which is in these terms The department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ision on this point is final despite it being wrong in law. In India this question is governed by section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 whi

arguments.court_reasoning: Arbitrator erred in construing clause 6; it is express term against remote consequences like rain damage

arguments.claim: Clause 6 refers only to cases where department has no control; applies to damage not total destruction; department at fault

anchor.surface_text: Item 5.-Loss of katcha bricks Rs. 75,900. The chief reason of the destruction of these bricks was the failure of the department to lift the monthly quota of bricks The argument of the department that they are not liable to compensate us on this account because of clause 6 of the agreement is not correct. Clause 6 refers to only such cases over which the department has no control.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ision on this point is final despite it being wrong in law. In India this question is governed by section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 whi

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause 6 absolute, covers any cause; expressly contemplated rain risk

arguments.claim: Clause 6 not meant to absolve department from carrying out their part of contract

anchor.surface_text: The contractor maintained that clause 6 of the contract could not be invoked when the department was at fault as in this case. Clause 6 was meant to cover contingencies which were not of the departments own making. I hold that the removal of the bricks in such a manner or to prevent accumulation in excess of 60 lacs was an implied contractual obligation on the part of the C.P.W.D I further hold that the C.P.W.D. cannot take shelter behind clause 6 of the contract.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ision on this point is final despite it being wrong in law. In India this question is governed by section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 whi

arguments.court_reasoning: Arbitrator wrong in law; clause express and absolute

arguments.claim: Arbitrator erred in law by awarding on item 5 as clause 6 bars it; error apparent on face

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator held that this clause was not meant to absolve the department from carrying out their part of the contract and so he awarded the contractor Rs. 64,075 under this head. We are clear that the arbitrator went wrong in law. ... There can therefore be no doubt that the arbitrator was wrong in his law. His construction of the terms of the contract was at fault.

arguments.claim: Contractor entitled to extra wages Rs.51,495 for coolies due to non-supply of ration and cloth; promise by department

anchor.surface_text: The next head in dispute is item No. 8 in the statement of claim Cost of additional wages paid to the coolies on account of non-supply of ration and cloth-Rs. 51,495. ... At the time when this work was allotted to us there was rationing system in the locality. As per conditions of contract we were bound not to employ local labour and we had to import coolies from far off places.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tractual obligation on the part of the C.P.W.D I further hold that the C.P.W.D. cannot take shelter behind clause 6 of the companytract. This clause i

arguments.court_reasoning: No collateral contract; govt contracts require proper authority signature; error apparent

arguments.claim: Circumstantial evidence proves mutual understanding/promise for ration supply

anchor.surface_text: From a perusal of these letters it is clear that the department promised us to supply ration These circumstantial evidences are sufficient enough to show that there was a mutual understanding between the parties that ration will be supplied. In the eyes of law even circumstantial evidence is sufficient to prove that such a promise was made.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: It ran- Provided always that in case any dispute or difference shall arise as to the companystruction of the companytract or as to any matter or thing

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts cannot be found from mere contention; signed contract without term; no acceptance

arguments.claim: Implied contractual obligation for P.W.D. to supply controlled rations; low tender rates evidence expectation

anchor.surface_text: the contractor contended that the very fact that he tendered such low rates showed that he expected to supply his labourers with rations at controlled rates. The arbitrator then sets out some more of the contractors contentions and from them concludes that there was an implied contractual obligation for the P.W.D. to make available controlled rations to the contractor

court_response_anchor.surface_text: It ran- Provided always that in case any dispute or difference shall arise as to the companystruction of the companytract or as to any matter or thing

arguments.court_reasoning: Error in law; no evidence or admission; one-sided contention; rationing provincial matter

arguments.claim: No collateral or implied promise for rations/cloth; govt bound only by signed contracts by proper authority

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that governments can only be bound by contracts that are entered into in a particular way and which are signed by the proper authority. ... It is an error in law to deduce from this that there was acceptance of the fresh proposal. On the contrary, the legal conclusion is that the new suggestion was dropped

arguments.claim: Arbitrator erred in law on item 8 by finding implied obligation from contentions alone

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly awarded Rs. 40,000 as compensation under this head. The error is apparent. -Facts must be based either on evidence or on admissions they cannot be found to exist from a mere contention by one side especially when they are expressly denied by the other.

arguments.claim: Item 8 claim not covered by arbitration clause if collateral contract

anchor.surface_text: If this implied agreement about rations and cloth does not spring out of the written contract but is to be inferred collaterally as a distinct and subsidiary contract, and we gather that that is the finding, especially as reference was made to section 9 of the Contract Act, then that is not a contract to which the arbitration clause can apply.

arguments.claim: Contractor entitled to interest Rs.27,665 at 6% for 16 months from 1-1-1948 as claims should have been settled by then

anchor.surface_text: Item 17-Interest on the amount of money involved in this claim at the rate of Rs. 6 percent.Rs. 27,665. ... We therefore pray for interest for 16 months from 1-1-48 to 31-4-49.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: fact that he tendered such low rates showed that he expected to supply his labourers with rations at companytrolled rates. The arbitrator then sets o

arguments.court_reasoning: No power under Interest Act 1839; unliquidated sums, no demand, not debt certain; arbitrator not court under CPC s.34

arguments.claim: Interest awardable as reasonable; claims should have been settled by Jan 1948

anchor.surface_text: The contractors contention that his claims should have been settled by January 1948 is, in my opinion, reasonable. I therefore award interest at 6 for 16 months on the total amount of the awards given i.e., Rs. 17,363.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: fact that he tendered such low rates showed that he expected to supply his labourers with rations at companytrolled rates. The arbitrator then sets o

arguments.court_reasoning: Conditions of Interest Act not met; unliquidated claims

arguments.claim: Arbitrator has no power to award interest; conditions of Interest Act 1839 not satisfied

anchor.surface_text: The Interest Act, 1839 applies, as interest is not otherwise payable by law in this kind of case ... Not one of these elements is present, so the arbitrator erred in law in thinking that he had the power to allow interest simply because he thought the demand was reasonable.

arguments.claim: Courts can review arbitrator's error of law on face of award unless question of law specifically referred

anchor.surface_text: The question now arises whether his decision on this point is final despite it being wrong in law. In India this question is governed by section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 which empowers a Court to remit an award for reconsideration where an objection to the legality of the award is apparent upon the face of it.

arguments.claim: No specific reference of question of law re clause 6 or construction; thus reviewable

anchor.surface_text: a distinction must be drawn between cases in which a question of law is specifically referred ... We have next to see whether the arbitrator was specifically asked to construe clause 6 of the contract or any part of the contract, or whether any question of law was specifically referred.

arguments.claim: Arbitrator bound by law, not conciliator; error on face set right by courts unless specific referral

anchor.surface_text: An arbitrator is not a conciliator and cannot ignore the law or misapply it in order to do what he thinks is just and reasonable. He is a tribunal selected by the parties to decide their disputes according to law and so is bound to follow and apply the law, and if he does not, he can be set right by the Courts provided his error appears on the face of the award

arguments.claim: Error on clause 6 apparent on face of award

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the error is apparent on the face of the award. That in our opinion, is clear from the passages we have quoted from the award. We hold that clause 6 expressly relieves the Union Government of all liability under this head of claim

arguments.claim: High Court right in dismissing disputed claims in both appeals

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in dismissing the claims made under the heads in dispute here.

holdings.text: The arbitrator went wrong in law in construing clause 6 of the contract and awarding Rs. 64,075 for loss of katcha bricks as clause 6 expressly bars claims for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator held that this clause was not meant to absolve the department from carrying out their part of the contract and so he awarded the contractor Rs. 64,075 under this head. We are clear that the arbitrator went wrong in law. Government departments have their difficulties no less than contractors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 6 is absolute term contemplating remote risks like rain; contractor bound by express agreement; damages too remote, duty to mitigate under s.73 Contract Act.

holdings.text: Error of law in arbitrator's construction of clause 6 is apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the error is apparent on the face of the award. That in our opinion, is clear from the passages we have quoted from the award. We hold that clause 6 expressly relieves the Union Government of all liability under this head of claim

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrator's reasoning quoted in award shows misconstruction despite express terms.

holdings.text: No specific reference of question of law regarding construction of clause 6 or any part of the contract to the arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: We have next to see whether the arbitrator was specifically asked to construe clause 6 of the contract or any part of the contract, or whether any question of law was specifically referred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference general; clause 6 raised incidentally by parties in claims, not as separate distinct matter agreed by both.

holdings.text: Arbitrator's decision on question of law not final if error apparent on face unless specifically referred as separate matter.

anchor.surface_text: In India this question is governed by section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 which empowers a Court to remit an award for reconsideration where an objection to the legality of the award is apparent upon the face of it. This covers cases in which an error of law appears

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between incidental legal questions and specific referrals; follows English precedents like Absalom and Privy Council cases.

holdings.text: An arbitrator is bound to follow and apply the law and can be corrected by courts if error appears on the face of the award, unless parties specifically refer a question of law.

anchor.surface_text: An arbitrator is not a conciliator and cannot ignore the law or misapply it in order to do what he thinks is just and reasonable. He is a tribunal selected by the parties to decide their disputes according to law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrator acts as tribunal per law, not equity; single exception for specific legal referrals.

holdings.text: No enforceable collateral or implied contract for supply of rations and cloth; government bound only by written contracts signed by proper authority.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that governments can only be bound by contracts that are entered into in a particular way and which are signed by the proper authority. A reference to the agreement, Ex. A 1 , will show that it was accepted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed contract lacks term; one-sided contentions not evidence; new proposal dropped by signing without inclusion.

holdings.text: Arbitrator erred in law by inferring implied contractual obligation for rations from contractor's mere contentions without evidence or admissions.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly awarded Rs. 40,000 as compensation under this head. The error is apparent. -Facts must be based either on evidence or on admissions they cannot be found to exist from a mere contention by one side

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts require evidence/admissions, not unilateral assertions denied by other party.

holdings.text: Arbitrator erred in law by awarding interest as conditions of Interest Act 1839 not satisfied; no power to award on reasonableness alone.

anchor.surface_text: The Interest Act, 1839 applies, as interest is not otherwise payable by law in this kind of case ... Not one of these elements is present, so the arbitrator erred in law in thinking that he had the power to allow interest simply because he thought the demand was reasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unliquidated sums, no certain debt/time, no written demand; s.34 CPC inapplicable to arbitrators.

holdings.text: Same errors and holdings apply to Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954; High Court right in dismissing disputed claims.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in dismissing the claims made under the heads in dispute here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Identical facts, contract, arbitrator; same legal errors apparent.
